Award.AbstractNarration:
This NSF award provides funding for a project to develop new methods for working with objects with complicated geometry at many different scales. Coastlines, clouds, and leaves are examples of such objects that occur in nature. The famous coastline paradox states that since a coastline is so rough at so many different scales, it has no defined length. The PI plans to develop and study new methods to build such multiscale objects and to break them down into easily handled pieces. New ways to decompose objects often lead to great advances in mathematics, where simple problems can have complicated, multiscale solutions. The projectâ€™s three-prong approach includes studying ways to break down complex objects, build complex objects out of simple pieces, and to measure multiscale complexity. In addition to the research, the PI will train graduate students and postdocs in the techniques developed by this project through advising, seminars, minicourses, and reading groups and disseminate material on his webpage for public access.

The project aims to study problems in metric geometry, geometric measure theory, and harmonic analysis related to maps and surfaces with multiscale structure, that is, objects like Lipschitz and Holder maps or fractals, that are hard to approximate by affine maps or by planes. One focus is the study of geometric problems that have non-smooth solutions but no smooth solutions, such as the Nash Embedding Theorem. Solutions to these problems often use multiscale or self-similar structure to break rules that smooth maps have to satisfy, and one aim of this project is to understand when and why this phenomenon occurs. Another focus is quantitative and uniform rectifiability. Uniform rectifiability has been a powerful tool for studying singular integrals and geometric measure theory in Euclidean space. Recent work has made it possible to find sharp bounds on the quantitative rectifiability of surfaces in the Heisenberg group, and this project will explore the possibility of extending notions of uniform rectifiability to the Heisenberg group and using them to solve problems in the geometry of Euclidean space and the Heisenberg group.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop new methods for working with objects with complicated geometry at many different scales. Many natural objects, such as leaves, clouds, and coastlines, have multiscale structure like this, and studying objects like this can lead to new tools and ideas. Over the course of the project, we studied ways to analyze and break down complex objects into simpler pieces and how to use multiscale methods to build complex and unexpected objects.

One of the main outcomes of the project is some major advances in the study of surfaces in the Heisenberg group. The Heisenberg group is an important example of noncommutativity, a phenomenon where the result of a series of actions depends on the order in which the actions are performed. The Heisenberg group is one of the simplest examples of noncommutativity in geometry; it is a three-dimensional space where moving around in a circle, as in Figure 1, can take you up or down. While this seems unusual, geometry like this occurs in situations like parallel parking a car.

In this project, we studied how this noncommutativity affects surfaces in the Heisenberg group. Specifically, one can use a branch of analysis known as uniform rectifiability to measure the complexity of a surface. Our results describe this complexity for a class of surfaces called intrinsic Lipschitz graphs. We show that, surprisingly, while surfaces in higher-dimensional Heisenberg groups behave similarly to surfaces in the usual Euclidean space, surfaces in the three-dimensional Heisenberg group can be rougher and more complex. This gives us new insight into the geometry of the Heisenberg group and opens the possibility of spaces where surfaces can be even more complex.

Another main outcome is a set of advances in the study of minimal surfaces in the Heisenberg group. In three-dimensional Euclidean space, minimal surfaces are smooth. We see this when we blow a soap bubble; the soap film tries to take a shape which encloses the most volume for a given area, which is a round sphere. In the Heisenberg group, it is still unknown what shape a soap bubble would take. The conjectured answer is a surface called the Pansu bubble set, which has singularities at the top and bottom, but proving this might require careful analysis of the singularities of minimal surfaces. The results of this project include new constructions of minimal surfaces in the Heisenberg group with a wide variety of singularities, including cases with infinitely many singularities, like Figure 2. The project also developed new tools for studying these singularities, which bring us closer to eventually answering the question.

Additional results of this project include advances in understanding how the geometry of nilpotent groups determines their structure, describing the geometry of metric spaces that satisfy local higher connectivity properties, and solving certain optimization problems by constructing surfaces out of families of parallel planes.

Overall, this project has advanced our understanding of geometry in Euclidean space and in metric spaces, and by introducing these techniques and ideas to a wide audience of mathematicians and students through courses, seminars, and expository articles, it has helped to build mathematical talent and expertise.
